metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into two equal parts.

prompt.text: Place a tick mark to divide into halves.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Place the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] in the middle.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal spacing highlighted

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. To make two equal parts, [event:A_compare] the distance from 0 to your [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] should equal the distance from your tick mark to 1.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the 1/2 tick mark to demonstrate the correct placement

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to divide this into halves. To split the [vocab]number line[/vocab] into two equal parts, [event:A_arrow] we place the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] exactly halfway between 0 and 1. See how the two intervals are exactly the same length? That's what makes them halves.

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You divided the line into halves.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at one-half.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check which [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] is halfway between 0 and 1.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to highlight equal intervals

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. One-half is the point that divides the line into two equal parts. [event:A_compare] Look at which [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] creates equal distances on both sides.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the 1/2 tick mark to show the correct location

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. One-half is located [event:A_arrow] at the middle tick mark between 0 and 1. This tick divides the number line into two equal parts, so it represents one-half. That's how we identify [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction] on a number line.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified one-half on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into three equal parts.

prompt.text: Place tick marks to partition into thirds.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Place two tick marks to make three equal parts.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing needed

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] To make thirds, you need three equal spaces between 0 and 1.

events.name: A_cut_1_3
events.description: Make a cut at 1/3 mark

events.name: A_cut_2_3
events.description: Make a cut at 2/3 mark

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to [vocab]partition[/vocab] into thirds. [event:A_cut_1_3][event:A_cut_2_3] We place one tick at one-third and another at two-thirds. See how this creates three [vocab]equal intervals[/vocab]? That's how thirds work on a [vocab]number line[/vocab].

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You partitioned the line into thirds.

steps.dialogue: Now find the tick that shows two-thirds.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=2 denominator=3][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check again. Count two thirds from zero.

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Compare the shaded parts to highlight the two-thirds position

step.dialogue: You're working on it. Here's what helps - [event:A_compare_shaded] two-thirds means two of the three equal parts from zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the 2/3 tick to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. [event:A_arrow] To find two-thirds, we count two equal jumps from zero. The first tick is one-third, and the second tick is two-thirds. That's the tick that shows two out of three equal parts.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified two-thirds on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into fourths by placing tick marks.

prompt.text: Place tick marks to divide into fourths.

step.dialogue: Check the spacing between marks.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] You need to make 4 equal parts, so the space between each [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] should be the same.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal spacing

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Highlight and compare each interval to show they are equal

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to divide this into fourths. [event:A_compare] To make four equal parts, we need three tick marks that split the line evenly. [event:A_compare_shaded] Each section from 0 to [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], then [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] to [fraction numerator=2 denominator=4]two fourths[/fraction], then [fraction numerator=2 denominator=4]two fourths[/fraction] to [fraction numerator=3 denominator=4]three fourths[/fraction], and finally [fraction numerator=3 denominator=4]three fourths[/fraction] to 1 should be exactly the same length. That's how fourths work - 4 equal parts make a whole.

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You divided the [vocab]number line[/vocab] into fourths.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at three-fourths.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=3 denominator=4][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count three fourths from zero.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show the intervals

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Highlight the first three intervals to show three-fourths

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. [event:A_compare] Three-fourths means we count three intervals of one-fourth each, starting from zero. [event:A_compare_shaded] Look at where the third interval ends.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the 3/4 tick mark to show counting three intervals

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. [event:A_arrow] To find three-fourths, we start at zero and count three equal jumps. The first jump takes us to [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], the second jump to [fraction numerator=2 denominator=4]two fourths[/fraction], and the third jump lands us right here at [fraction numerator=3 denominator=4]three fourths[/fraction]. See how we counted three intervals of one-fourth each to reach three-fourths.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified three-fourths on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into six equal parts.

prompt.text: Partition the number line into sixths.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Place five ticks to create six equal parts.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] To make sixths, you need six equal spaces between 0 and 1. That means placing five tick marks evenly along the line.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow showing equal spacing for all six intervals

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to [vocab]partition[/vocab] this into sixths. [event:A_arrow] To create six equal parts, we place five ticks that divide the line evenly from 0 to 1. See how each space between the ticks is exactly the same size? That's how sixths work - six [vocab]equal intervals[/vocab] on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You partitioned the line into sixths.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] that shows five-sixths.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=5 denominator=6][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check again. Count five intervals from zero.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line highlighting the five intervals

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. [event:A_compare] Five-sixths means we count five equal parts starting from zero. Look at which [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] comes after the fifth [vocab]interval[/vocab].

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the tick at 5/6 to help count the fraction

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. [event:A_arrow] To find five-sixths, we start at zero and count five [vocab]equal intervals[/vocab] along the [vocab]number line[/vocab]. The [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at the end of the fifth interval is five-sixths. That's how we locate [vocab]fractions[/vocab] on a number line - by counting the intervals from zero.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified five-sixths on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into thirds by placing tick marks.

prompt.text: Place tick marks to divide into thirds.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Place two tick marks to create three equal parts.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing needed

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. For thirds, you need [event:A_compare] two tick marks that divide the line into three equal sections.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal spacing demonstration

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to divide this into thirds. We need to place [event:A_compare] two tick marks that split the line into three equal parts - one at the one-third [vocab]position[/vocab] and one at the two-thirds position. See how each section is exactly the same length? That's what makes them thirds.

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You divided the line into three equal parts.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at one-third.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check again. Find the first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] after zero.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts to highlight the first interval representing 1/3

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. One-third is [event:A_compare] the first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] you reach when counting from zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draws an arrow from 0 to the first tick mark at 1/3

step.dialogue: Let me help you with this. To find one-third, we start at zero and [event:A_arrow] move to the first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab]. That first tick represents one out of three equal parts. That's one-third.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified one-third on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into four equal parts by placing tick marks.

prompt.text: Place tick marks to partition into fourths.

step.dialogue: Check the spacing between marks.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] You need four equal parts between 0 and 1, so the spacing between each [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] should be exactly the same.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Demonstrate equal spacing by showing measurement of all four intervals on the number line

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to [vocab]partition[/vocab] this into fourths. [event:A_compare] To make four equal parts, we need to divide the distance from 0 to 1 into four sections that are all the same size. That means placing tick marks at one-fourth, two-fourths, and three-fourths. See how each [vocab]interval[/vocab] is exactly the same length?

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You partitioned the line into fourths.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] that shows one-fourth.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count one fourth from zero.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Highlight all four equal intervals on the number line

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Highlight the first interval from 0 to the first tick mark

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. [event:A_compare] One-fourth means one part out of four equal parts. [event:A_compare_shaded] Start at zero and move to the first [vocab]tick mark[/vocab].

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the first tick mark to show one-fourth

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. [event:A_arrow] One-fourth is the first tick mark after zero. We start at 0 and count one equal part forward - that's the first tick mark, which represents one-fourth. That's how we locate one-fourth on a [vocab]number line[/vocab].

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified one-fourth on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into six equal parts.

prompt.text: Place tick marks to divide into sixths.

step.dialogue: Check the spacing between marks.

events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line to show equal spacing

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. You need to make six equal parts between 0 and 1. [event:A_compare] Try spacing the tick marks evenly.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Demonstrate equal spacing by showing measurement of all six equal intervals

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to divide this into sixths. To make six equal parts, we need to place five tick marks [event:A_compare] that divide the line evenly from 0 to 1. See how each section is exactly the same size? That's how sixths work - six equal parts make a whole.

on_correct.dialogue: Good. You divided the line into sixths.

steps.dialogue: Now find the [vocab]tick mark[/vocab] at four-sixths.

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=4 denominator=6][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Count four sixths from zero.

events.name: A_compare_shaded
events.description: Highlight the first four intervals to show counting to 4/6

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. [event:A_compare_shaded] Four-sixths means we count four equal jumps from zero.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the 4/6 tick mark showing the counting progression

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. To find four-sixths, we start at zero and count four equal parts: [event:A_arrow] one-sixth, two-sixths, three-sixths, four-sixths. That's how we locate four-sixths on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. You identified four-sixths on the [vocab]number line[/vocab].

metadata.goal_text: The student can partition a number line into equal parts and label the given fraction.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into three equal parts by placing tick marks.

events.name: A_compare

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to [vocab]partition[/vocab] into thirds. To divide the [vocab]number line[/vocab] into three equal parts, we need to place [event:A_compare] tick marks at [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] and [fraction numerator=2 denominator=3]two thirds[/fraction]. steps.dialogue: Now find the tick that represents [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3]3 thirds[/fraction].

prompt.text: Select the tick at [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3][/fraction].

step.dialogue: Check again. Count three thirds from zero.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Highlight the three equal intervals to show how they add up to one whole

step.dialogue: You're working on it. Here's what helps - [event:A_compare] three thirds equals one whole, so [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3]3 thirds[/fraction] is at the same place as 1.

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the tick at 1 to show counting three thirds

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. We need to find [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3]3 thirds[/fraction]. [event:A_arrow] Starting at zero, we count three thirds: one third, two thirds, three thirds. Three thirds equals one whole, so [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3]3 thirds[/fraction] is right at the 1 mark. That's how thirds work - three equal parts make a whole.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. [fraction numerator=3 denominator=3]3 thirds[/fraction] is at the end, equal to one whole.

That's what makes them fourths.

steps.dialogue: Here's a [vocab]number line[/vocab] from 0 to 1. Divide it into fourths by placing tick marks.

step.dialogue: Let's think about this together. [event:A_compare] To make fourths, you need four equal spaces between 0 and 1.

step.dialogue: Let me show you how to divide this into fourths. [event:A_compare] We need to place tick marks so the distance from 0 to the first tick, the first tick to the second tick, the second tick to the third tick, and the third tick to 1 are all equal. [event:A_arrow] That creates four equal parts called fourths.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

step.dialogue: Here's a hint. [event:A_compare] Count all four parts from 0. Four fourths equals one whole, so [fraction numerator=4 denominator=4]4 fourths[/fraction] is at the same place as 1.

events.name: A_compare
events.description: Compare all the parts of the number line with equal parts

events.name: A_arrow
events.description: Draw an arrow from 0 to the endpoint at 1 to show counting four fourths

step.dialogue: Let me walk you through this. [event:A_compare] We have four equal parts on this number line. [event:A_arrow] When we count all four fourths from 0, we end up at 1. That's because [fraction numerator=4 denominator=4]4 fourths[/fraction] equals one whole. See how [fraction numerator=4 denominator=4]4 fourths[/fraction] and 1 are at the exact same spot?

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. [fraction numerator=4 denominator=4]4 fourths[/fraction] is at the end, equal to 1 whole.
